I.     INTRODUCTION
ConocoPhillips Company is proposing to build a new research and office development in the
City of Louisville, Colorado. The new facility would be located north of US 36 between South
88th Street and Northwest Parkway and was the former location of Storage Technology
Corporation. The precise location can be seen as shown in Figure 1.

The proposed ConocoPhillips Campus site is located northwest of the Northwest Parkway / US
36 interchange. The overall site is approximately 432 acres with the PDP boundary including
390 acres. The current site is a developed parcel in which all existing structures have been
razed and will be replaced with the new development. At build out, the total development will not
exceed 2.5 million square feet (msf). The conceptual layout for the site includes an initial phase
totaling 1.60 msf initial occupancy of which is anticipated in 2013, Phase 2 totaling 0.15 msf of
additional development with initial occupancy thereof anticipated in 2018, and Phase 3 (Build
Out) totaling 0.75 msf of additional development with initial occupancy anticipated in 2032.

The proposed development in the initial phase is expected to include the following land uses:
        Office space;
        Research center;
        Learning center;
        On-site hotel; and
        Support services.

The proposed development in Phase 2 is expected to include the following land uses:
        Additional research center;

The build out of the proposed development is expected to include the following additional land
use:
        Additional office space; and
        Additional research center.

A conceptual site plan is shown in Figure 2.

This report is intended to serve as the traffic impact study for the development. It presents the
estimated traffic impacts on the surrounding roadway network as well as the roadway and
intersection improvements necessary to accommodate the additional traffic demand.

II.       EXISTING CONDITIONS
A.        Land Use

All of the former Storage technology Corporation buildings have been deconstructed. The site is
currently unoccupied and therefore contributes no traffic to the surrounding road network.

North of the site, along Campus Drive, are Monarch High School and Monarch K-8. To the west,
across South 88th Street at the intersection with Campus Drive, is Avista Adventist Hospital.
Located south of the site across the US 36 and South 96th Street interchange is the Flatiron
Mall.

B.        Roadways

         Dillon Road is an east-west arterial roadway that extends east from McCaslin Boulevard
          to South 96th Street in the study area. The roadway has two lanes in each direction
          between McCaslin Boulevard and South 88th Street with exclusive turn lanes and one
          through lane in each direction between South 88th Street and South 96th Street. The
          posted speed limit in the vicinity of the site is 35 miles per hour.

         Northwest Parkway is an east-west expressway east of South 96th Street that turns
          south at the South 96th Street intersection to become a north-south arterial roadway.
          The roadway has two lanes in each direction with exclusive turn lanes at the
          intersections. The posted speed limit in the vicinity of the site is 40 miles per hour.
          Northwest Parkway becomes a limited access toll road northeast of the intersection with
          South 96th Street.

         US 36 is classified in the State Highway Access Category Assignment Schedule as an
          east-west freeway that provides inter-regional access from Denver to Boulder. The
          freeway has two lanes in each direction, and the posted speed limit is 65 miles per hour.

         South 88th Street is a north-south arterial street that extends south from Dillon Road to
          Rock Creek Parkway in the vicinity of the site. The roadway has one lane in each
          direction, and the posted speed limit is 35 miles per hour.

         South 96th Street is a north-south arterial roadway that extends north from Northwest
          Parkway in the vicinity of the site. The roadway has one lane in each direction, and the
          posted speed limit is 40 miles per hour. In addition, at the intersection of South 96th
          Street / Dillon Road, each roadway has been widened to two through lanes in each
          direction at the signal.

         Campus Drive is an east-west collector roadway that extends east from South 88th
          Street approximately 2,200 feet to the east end of Monarch High School. The roadway
          has one lane in each direction with exclusive turn lanes that provide access to the high
          school and K-8. The posted speed limit is 25 miles per hour.




                                                                                             Page 4
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                          Traffic Impact Study



C.     Traffic Volumes

Traffic counts were collected by Navjoy Consulting Services during typical weekday operations
in August, 2008. These counts were taken at the 16 intersections in the study area. Peak hour
traffic volumes are contained in Figure 3. Count data is included in Appendix A for reference.

Special consideration was given to the intersection of South 88th Street / Campus Drive due to
Monarch High School and Monarch K-8 School and heavy peak loading at the intersection due
to the concentration of student activity right before the school start times. The movements
associated with school traffic were therefore analyzed considering the measured peak hour
factor (PHF) to provide an accurate measure of the AM peak hour LOS at the intersection. Peak
hour factors are a measure of how "peaked" the highest 15-minute period is during the peak
hour. At this intersection, the affected movements experience an average PHF equal to 0.75
during the AM peak hour. The "normal" PHF is approximately 0.92. Using the lower PHF (0.74)
means that the high peaking characteristics have been properly accounted for in the analyses.

Current traffic patterns around the site primarily consist of traffic passing north-south adjacent to
the site between the Flatiron Crossing area and US 36, to the south, and the City of Louisville,
to the north. In addition, significant traffic volumes along US 36 exist as the roadway connects
the cities of Denver and Boulder.

D.     Traffic Operations

The existing traffic operational conditions were analyzed at each of the study intersections
based on procedures documented in the Highway Capacity Manual, (Transportation Research
Board, Third Edition, 2000). This analysis procedure provides a level of service (LOS) which is a
qualitative measure based on the average delay per vehicle at a controlled intersection. Levels
of service are described by a letter ranging from "A" to "F". LOS A represents minimal delay,
while LOS F represents excessive congestion and delay. LOS D is typically the minimal LOS
used for design of intersections. The signalized intersection analyses report a level of service
rating for the entire intersection while the unsignalized analyses report a level of service rating
for each movement. Synchro software was used to develop the LOS calculations. The operation
of the roundabout at Rock Creek Boulevard and South 88th Street was evaluated using Sidra
Intersection software.

Level of service analyses were conducted for the existing traffic volumes. Figure 4 shows the
2008 lane geometry and levels of service at the study intersections. Appendix B provides the
operational analysis worksheets.

The existing scenario shows that all study area intersections currently operate at LOS D or
better during the AM and PM peak periods. These calculations were done with the existing
signal timings. The analyses also revealed that traffic signal timing modifications could improve
existing operations at some intersections within the study area. Optimized signal timings are
also shown on Figure 4.

         ULLE VI G                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         NORTH
Conoco Phillips Campus - Louisville, 09-123, 11/04/09
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                       Traffic Impact Study



III.   PROPOSED PROJECT
A.     Land Use

The proposed ConocoPhillips Campus site is located northwest of the Northwest Parkway / US
36 interchange. The overall site is approximately 432 acres with the PDP boundary including
390 acres. The current site is a developed parcel in which all existing structures have been
razed and will be replaced with the new development. At build out, the total development will not
exceed 2.5 million square feet (msf). The conceptual layout for the site includes an initial phase
totaling 1.60 msf initial occupancy of which is anticipated in 2013, Phase 2 totaling 0.15 msf of
additional development with initial occupancy thereof anticipated in 2018, and Phase 3 (Build
Out) totaling 0.75 msf of additional development with initial occupancy anticipated in 2032.

The proposed development in the initial phase is expected to include the following land uses:
        Office space  472,647 sf;
        Research center  502,617 sf;
        Learning center  34,967 sf;
        Internal hotel  120 rooms; and
        Support services  183 employees.

The proposed development in Phase 2 is expected to include the following additional land uses:
        Research center  135,630 sf;

The build out of the proposed development is expected to include the following additional land
use:
        Office space  299,155 sf; and
        Research center  437,451 sf.

B.     Trip Generation

The number of daily vehicle trips that would be generated by the ConocoPhillips Campus was
forecasted based on trip rates and procedures documented in Trip Generation (Institute of
Transportation Engineers, Eighth Edition, 2008). The land use codes 715  Single Tenant Office
Building, 760  Research and Development Center, and 312  Business Hotel were used to
generate trips for the site. Table 1 summarizes the trip generation estimates used for the
proposed Phase 1 development. A four percent modal split reduction was estimated for the
Phase 1 development. This nominal mode share can be attributed to the regional modal split
forecasted by DRCOG and the proximity of regional bus service provided at the East Flatiron
Circle park-n-Ride. This modal split estimate is less than that forecasted for the US 36 corridor
in the on-going environmental studies.




                                                                                           Page 8
 ConocoPhillips Campus                                                                                      Traffic Impact Study



 Table 1.             Phase 1 Trip Generation Characteristics

                       Trip Generation                                                        Weekday
                                                                                       AM Peak Hour                 PM Peak Hour
          Land Use                  LUC      Size         Units          Daily
                                                                                      In   Out Total              In   Out   Total
General Office                       715      473        ksf             5,468       757   94    851             122 695      817
R & D Center                         760      503        ksf             4,076       509 104 613                 81    457    538
Learning Center1                     715      35         ksf              101        14     2     16              2     13     15
Learning Center Lodging2             312      100      Rooms               73         3     3     6               4     2      6
Regional Center Hotel                312      20       Rooms              145         7     5    12               7     5     12
Support Services                     715      183     Employees           662         86   11     97             14     78     92
                                   Site Generated Traffic               10,500      1,375      220     1,595     230     1,250      1,480
                                Mode Split Reduction (4%)                400         55        10        65      10        50         60
                                                    Total               10,100      1,320      210     1,530     220     1,200      1,420
 1
   The learning center is a facility that will be designed to accommodate training classes for ConocoPhillips employees from
    throughout the company. Most of the employees will fly to the Denver metro area and be shuttled to the facility during the off
    peak. As a result, the number of trips expected from a facility of this type will be greatly reduced. It is assumed that trips to the
    learning center will be made by local employees and support staff.
 2
   The learning center lodging is a facility that will accommodate ConocoPhillips employees who have traveled to Denver for training
    at the learning center. As a result, the number of trips expected from a facility of this type will be greatly reduced. It is assumed
    that trips to the hotel will be made by support staff.

 Table 2 summarizes the trip generation estimates used for the proposed Build Out development
 of the ConocoPhillips Campus. A six percent modal split reduction has been taken for the Build
 Out development based on the increased level of transit service anticipated in the future along
 the US 36 corridor.
 Table 2.             Build Out Trip Generation Characteristics

                       Trip Generation                                                         Weekday
                                                                                        AM Peak Hour                 PM Peak Hour
         Land Use                  LUC       Size          Units          Daily
                                                                                       In   Out Total              In   Out   Total
General Office                      715      772          ksf             8,930      1,236 153 1,389              200 1,135 1,335
R & D Center                        760     1,076         ksf             8,724      1,089 223 1,312              173 978 1,151
Learning Center1                    715       35          ksf              101         14    2    16               2     13    15
Learning Center Lodging2            312      100        Rooms               73         3     3     6               4     2      6
Regional Center Hotel               312       20        Rooms              145         7     5    12               7     5     12
Support Services                    715      183       Employees           662         86   11    97              14     78    92
                                                   Totals                18,600      2,435     395      2,830     400     2,210      2,610
                                Mode Split Reduction (6%)                1,000        145      25        170      25       135        155
                                                    Total                17,500      2,290     370      2,660     375     2,075      2,455
 1
   The learning center is a facility that will be designed to accommodate training classes for ConocoPhillips employees from
    throughout the company. Most of the employees will fly to the Denver metro area and be shuttled to the facility during the off
    peak. As a result, the number of trips expected from a facility of this type will be greatly reduced. It is assumed that trips to the
    learning center will be made by local employees and support staff.
 2
   The learning center lodging is a facility that will accommodate ConocoPhillips employees who have traveled to Denver for training
    at the learning center. As a result, the number of trips expected from a facility of this type will be greatly reduced. It is assumed
    that trips to the hotel will be made by support staff.




                                                                                                                                 Page 9
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                       Traffic Impact Study



Trip generation reductions have been assumed for the Learning Center and associated
Learning Center Lodging anticipated for the ConocoPhillips Campus. Future use of these
facilities will provide training classes for ConocoPhillips employees from throughout the
company. Most of these employees will fly to the Denver metro area and be shuttled to the site.
The number of trips from these facilities will be reduced as a result of extensive carpooling and
the unique mission of the facilities.

As shown, the traffic generated at build out is approximately 17,500 vehicle-trips per day.
Approximately 2,660 new vehicle trips are anticipated to be added to the road network during
the AM peak hour and 2,455 during the PM peak hour. These numbers reflect an estimate of
the total of all trips in and out of the facility, that is, all access drives combined.

C.       Site Access

The development of the ConocoPhillips Campus is anticipated to occur in three phases with the
internal road network completed by Phase 1 construction. For Phase 1, Campus Drive would be
extended from its existing location at Monarch High School east to the intersection of South
96th Street / Paradise Lane. This new road would provide access to the north half of the site
through Site Access B. The existing Tape Drive access from StorageTek Drive on the southeast
corner of the site would be maintained to provide Site Access A. Site Access D from South 88th
Street on the west side of the site would be approximately 500 feet north of the location used by
StorageTek. In addition, a right-in/right-out (RIRO) access to Northwest Parkway would be
constructed to allow drivers to directly enter the property at Site Access C.

D.       Trip Distribution

The site trip distribution assumptions were developed based on the Denver Regional Council of
Governments (DRCOG) 2035 regional travel demand model. Trips were distributed as follows:

        15 percent to/from the north on South 88th Street
        10 percent to/from the north on South 96th Street
        20 percent to/from the east on the Northwest Parkway
        30 percent to/from the east on US 36
        10 percent to/from the south on Interlocken Loop
        5 percent to/from the south on South 88th Street
        10 percent to/from the west on US 36




                                                                                          Page 10
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                          Traffic Impact Study



The peak hour site generated traffic volumes were assigned to the study area roadway network
using the trip distribution shown above. The site was divided into north and south sides to
account for distinct travel patterns to different parts of the site based on the external and internal
road networks. This anticipated traffic for each side was assigned using anticipated parking
supply locations on the site to account for different routing decisions based on the
destination/origination of drivers to/from the site. In general, the largest percentage of trips
generated by the ConocoPhillips Campus, 30 percent, will arrive and depart using US 36 to the
southeast. Twenty percent of trips will utilize the Northwest Parkway to the northeast, and 15
percent will utilize South 88th Street to the north. The large number of trips accessing the site
from US 36 at 40 percent represents the regional importance of this roadway as a major
connection between Denver and Boulder. Figure 5 shows the trip distribution for the proposed
development site generated trips. Figure 6 and Figure 7 contain the forecasted trip
assignments for Phase 1 and Build Out development levels, respectively.

         H O LT &
         ULLE VI G                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 NORTH
Conoco Phillips Campus - Louisville, 09-123, 11/10/09
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                       Traffic Impact Study



IV.    BACKGROUND TRAFFIC
A.     Traffic Volumes

Background traffic is the component of traffic volume on the local street network that is not
related to the proposed ConocoPhillips development. In developing the background volumes,
traffic growth was calculated by combining growth projections from the DRCOG regional travel
demand model for 2035 with local developments having plans on record with the cities of
Broomfield and Louisville. Although build out of the ConocoPhillips Campus will occur by 2032,
the Long-Term Scenario for traffic analyses was chosen as 2035. This means that the traffic
forecasts are consistent with 2035 regional forecasts from DRCOG.

The background growth increases were developed using the DRCOG 2035 regional travel
demand model. The background growth rate generally represents increased through traffic
volumes due to additional regional growth surrounding a project site. Growth factors were
determined for individual corridors in the study area by comparing the 2005 and 2035 demand
models to determine the associated growth rate. The growth rate was then used to determine
growth factors for the Phase 1 (2008 to 2013) and the Long-Term Scenario (2008 to 2035)
scenarios. As mentioned previously, the ConocoPhillips Campus will be built out by 2032.
Table 3 shows the growth rate and growth factors for each corridor in the study area, which was
then used to increase the existing turning movement counts to account for anticipated
background growth.

Table 3.       Corridor Growth Factors

                                                                Phase 1           Long-Term
                 Corridor                     Growth Rate        (2013)         (2035) Growth
                                                              Growth Factor         Factor
 McCaslin Boulevard (south of US 36)            1.93 %            1.10               1.68
 South 88th Street                              1.83 %            1.10               1.64
 South 96th Street                              1.18 %            1.06               1.38
 Northwest Parkway                              1.18 %            1.06               1.38
 Dillon Road                                    1.46 %            1.08               1.48
 Rock Creek Parkway                             1.76 %            1.09               1.61
 Coalton Road                                   0.72 %            1.04               1.21

In addition to general background traffic growth, specific local developments were included in
the background analysis for three projects which currently have documents on record with the
cities of Broomfield and Louisville. Two of the developments are in the City of Broomfield and
are located east across Northwest Parkway from the ConocoPhillips Campus; the Parkway
Circle and Overlook developments were included in the background based on trip generations
presented in the associated studies. Twenty five percent of these developments were included
in the 2013 projection and the full developments were included in the 2035 projection. The third
development is the Avista Adventist Hospital which has submitted plans with the City of
Louisville to increase the current hospital from 350,000 sf to 750,000 sf. Further development of
the Avista Adventist Hospital is anticipated to occur in the long term and was therefore included
in the 2035 background traffic. See Figure 1 for the location of these developments.




                                                                                         Page 15
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                    Traffic Impact Study



Figure 8 and Figure 9 show the background traffic for the 2013 and 2035 background
scenarios, respectively. The 2013 short-term period corresponds with the planned completion of
Phase 1 of the ConocoPhillips Campus. Build out of the site is expected to be completed by
2032, but the Long-Term Scenario includes an additional three years growth through 2035.
Significant background growth is expected on the roadways surrounding the project site due to
continued development in the area. The significant growth on all roads surrounding the
ConocoPhillips Campus will therefore require City of Louisville and other local agencies to
construct roadway improvements to accommodate general growth in the study area, as
discussed in the next section.

Conoco Phillips Campus - Louisville, 09-123, 11/06/09
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                        Traffic Impact Study



B.     Traffic Operations

As previously mentioned, background traffic is the component of traffic volume on the local
street network that is not related to the proposed ConocoPhillips development. The same LOS
traffic analysis procedures that were discussed previously were applied to the 2013 and 2035
background traffic volumes. LOS and potential roadway improvements that will be the
responsibility of the City of Louisville and other local agencies to accommodate general growth
in the study area for each period are described in the following subsections.

2013

The 2013 background scenario was evaluated with optimized signal timing and existing
geometry at all intersections except for the following geometry changes.

       Northwest Parkway / South 96th Street - This intersection was assumed to be
       expanded to include a four leg intersection to serve the future redevelopment area east
       of Northwest Parkway in Broomfield.

       McCaslin Boulevard / Dillon Road - The City of Louisville will need to widen the
       westbound Dillon Road approach to McCaslin Boulevard to add a second full-use left
       turn lane. This will provide dual left-turn lanes, one through lane, and one right-turn lane
       for westbound traffic. Currently, there are three lanes (one left-turn lane, one shared
       left-through lane, and one right-turn lane), and the signal timing is inefficient due to the
       need for a split-phase. The following figure provides individual movement LOS ratings
       associated with two scenarios: first, if no improvements are made at the intersection and
       second, if the above recommendations for the westbound direction are adopted.




       As can be seen, without upgrading the intersection, split phasing is required for the east-
       west movements and the associated LOS are poor with four movements operating at
       LOS F during the PM peak hour. If the intersection upgrades are made, the intersection
       would operate with substantially better LOS with only one movement operating at LOS F
       in the PM peak hour. This comparison shows what is possible for the intersection if the




                                                                                           Page 19
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                      Traffic Impact Study



       westbound left-through is separated and split phasing is no longer required at the
       intersection. It is assumed that the above recommendations are implemented for the
       2013 background scenario in this report.

Figure 10 shows the lane geometries and levels of service for the 2013 background scenario.
With the above laneage improvements, all study area intersections would operate at LOS D or
better during the AM and PM peak periods.

2035

The 2035 background scenario was evaluated with optimized signal timing and the 2013
background geometry at all intersections except for the following geometry changes.

       Dillon Road - Dillon Road should be widened to four continuous through lanes from
       South 88th Street to east of the intersection with South 96th Street. Previous analyses
       have shown that this improvement may be necessary as soon as the 2020 to 2025
       timeframe.

       South 96th Street - South 96th Street should be widened to four continuous through
       lanes from north of Dillon Road to the intersection with Northwest Parkway. Previous
       analyses have shown that this improvement may be necessary as soon as the 2020 to
       2025 timeframe.

       Dillon Road / South 96th Street - At Dillon Road and South 96th Street dual left turn
       lanes should be provided for all movements. Again, previous analyses have shown that
       this improvement may be necessary as soon as the 2020 to 2025 timeframe.

       McCaslin Boulevard / Dillon Road - McCaslin Boulevard at the intersection with Dillon
       Road should be widened to provide three continuous through lanes in the northbound
       direction. This roadway improvement will likely involve significant impacts to surrounding
       properties.

       South 96th Street / Northwest Parkway - At South 96th Street and Northwest
       Parkway, a southbound free flowing, continuous right turn lane from South 96th Street to
       southbound Northwest Parkway should be provided.

       Northwest Parkway - This roadway should be widened to six continuous through lanes
       from the end of the tolled portion of the Northwest Parkway south to the intersection with
       the eastbound off ramp for US 36.

       McCaslin Boulevard - McCaslin Boulevard should be widened to four continuous
       through lanes north of Coalton Road.




                                                                                         Page 20
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                       Traffic Impact Study



Figure 11 shows the lane geometries and levels of service for the 2035 background scenario.
With the above laneage improvements, all study area intersections would operate at LOS D or
better during the AM and PM peak periods with the exception of the intersection of McCaslin
Boulevard / Dillon Road. This intersection would operate at LOS E in the PM peak hour even
with the previous recommendation of a third northbound through lane. Obtaining a LOS D at this
intersection would require further widening with significant impacts on the surrounding existing
development and therefore has not been recommended. Appendix C provides the operational
analysis worksheets.

Further evaluation of the South 96th Street / Northwest Parkway intersection shows that the
existing dual northbound left turn lanes will continue to accommodate the turning vehicles. While
the left turning volumes (1110 vehicles per hour during the PM peak hour) is very significant,
this recommendation is based on the availability of three southbound lanes from Northwest
Parkway and the small conflicting volume of 460 vehicles per hour during the same period. In
addition, the recommendation is based on forecasts that show limited growth to the east leg of
the intersection. If significant development were to occur on this parcel, the signal timing may
fail to provide enough green time to northbound left turning vehicles, and an additional left turn
lane may be required.

         ULLE VI G                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               NORTH
Conoco Phillips Campus - Louisville, 09-123, 11/04/09
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                        Traffic Impact Study



V.     TOTAL TRAFFIC
A.     Traffic Volumes

The site generated traffic was added to the background traffic for 2013 and 2035 scenarios to
estimate the total traffic volumes for each planning horizon. Figure 12 and Figure 13 show the
2013 and 2035 total traffic volumes, respectively.

As was discussed previously for the existing traffic volumes, peak loading due to the school at
the South 88th Street / Campus Drive intersection was considered as a part of the analysis. The
same PHF used for movements during the existing traffic AM peak hour volume analysis were
used for the background analysis. In order to account for the effects of the ConocoPhillips
Campus on the intersection, an assumed PHF of 0.92 (the same PHF used for all other
intersections in the study) was used for the new ConocoPhillips traffic, representing normal
peak 15 minute loading within the overall peak hour. A weighted average was used for total
traffic volumes to calculate the anticipated PHF for movements at the intersection at 2013 and
2035. The associated PHF (0.76 for 2013 and 2035) have been used in the following analysis
for the AM peak hour LOS.

B.     Traffic Operations

The same LOS traffic analysis procedures that were discussed previously were applied to the
2013 and 2035 total traffic volumes.

2013  Phase 1

The 2013 total scenario was evaluated with optimized signal timing and 2013 background
geometry at all intersections except for the following geometry changes.

       Campus Drive - Campus Drive should be extended east from its current terminus near
       Monarch High School as a two lane road to intersect with South 96th Street at Paradise
       Lane. This is the primary access to the north side of the site. Construct a southbound
       auxiliary right turn lane, a northbound auxiliary left turn lane, and an eastbound auxiliary
       right turn lane at the intersection of Campus Drive / South 96th Street. Signal warrants
       were evaluated, and the intersection of Campus Drive and South 96th Street should be
       signalized with initial construction.

       It is recommended that Campus Drive be constructed according to Louisville collector
       street standards. The functional classification of collector is recommended based on the
       following characteristics of the extension of this road.
       - The new roadway will function as a connection between the local driveways,
            Monarch schools, and ConocoPhillips and the arterial streets, South 88th Street and
            South 96th Street.
       - Arterial classification is not appropriate since arterials typically carry traffic with
            longer distance trips, and Campus Drive will be constructed as an approximately 1
            mile segment with limited prospects for future expansion.




                                                                                            Page 24
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                       Traffic Impact Study



       -   Existing Campus Drive has a speed limit of 25 mph near the school, and the future
           extension will likely also be set at a posted speed limit no greater than 30 or 35 mph.
       -   Although laneage and classification are not closely linked, Campus Drive will remain
           at 2 lanes (3,200 ADT west of South 96th Street to 6,900 ADT east of South 88th
           Street) at build out of the ConocoPhillips Campus.
       -   Louisville's collector standards for curves have been calculated with a design speed
           of 40 mph. The proposed curves on Campus Drive are more than adequate for
           30/35 mph posted speed limits and provide adequate sight distances and safety for a
           roadway of this type.

       Internal Road Network - All internal roadways will need to be completed to
       accommodate Phase 1 traffic. Phase 1 involves completion of significant portions of both
       the north and south sides of the site so convenient access will be necessary from Site
       Accesses A, B, C, and D. See Figure 2 for the labeled internal road network.
               Site Access A  No laneage improvements are required at this time. The
               existing northbound dual left turn lanes and the southbound right turn lane will
               provide acceptable traffic operations.
               Site Access B  Construct a westbound auxiliary left turn lane and an eastbound
               auxiliary right turn lane for inbound traffic. Separate northbound left turn and
               right turn lanes will be needed at the new site access to accommodate outbound
               traffic.
               Site Access C - This right-in/right-out only (RIRO) access point on Northwest
               Parkway should be constructed to provide direct access to the site to/from
               southbound Northwest Parkway.
               Site Access D  Construct a southbound auxiliary left turn lane and a
               northbound right turn deceleration lane for inbound traffic at this access.
               Outbound traffic will need separate westbound left turn and right turn lanes at the
               site access. The outbound volumes are not high enough at the completion of
               Phase 1 to warrant signalization. ConocoPhillips and the City of Louisville should
               monitor traffic volumes at this access point to determine when volumes meet
               appropriate Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) signal warrant.
               Street A  Construct as a four lane roadway.
               Street B  Construct as a two lane roadway.
               Street C  Construct as a two lane roadway.
               Street D  Construct as a two lane roadway.
               Street E  Construct as a two lane roadway.
               Street F  Construct as a two lane roadway.

Figure 14 shows the lane geometries and levels of service for the 2013 total scenario. With the
above laneage improvements, all study area intersections would operate at LOS D or better
during the AM and PM peak periods.

         ULLE VI G                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   NORTH
Conoco Phillips Campus - Louisville, 09-123, 11/04/09
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                       Traffic Impact Study



2035  Long-Term Scenario

Although build out of the ConocoPhillips Campus will occur by 2032, the Long-Term Scenario
for traffic analyses was chosen as 2035 in order that the traffic forecasts are consistent with
2035 regional forecasts from DRCOG. The 2035 total scenario was evaluated with optimized
signal timing and 2035 background geometry at all intersections except for the following
geometry changes.

       South 88th Street - South 88th Street should be widened to four continuous through
       lanes from Dillon Road to Campus Drive.

       Internal Road Network  Additional laneage improvements required for 2035 total
       traffic volumes, above those listed for the 2013 scenario, follow:
                Site Access A  Construct triple northbound left turn lanes on Northwest
                Parkway at the site access. Consider that this improvement requires the
                widening of Northwest Parkway surrounding the intersection and may be best
                accomplished at the same time the road widening of Northwest Parkway to six
                through lanes occurs.
                Site Access D  This intersection should be signalized when traffic counts show
                that traffic is sufficient to meet the appropriate MUTCD signal warrant.

Figure 15 shows the lane geometries and levels of service for the 2035 total scenario. With the
above laneage improvements, all study area intersections would operate at LOS D or better
during the AM and PM peak periods with the exception of the intersection of McCaslin
Boulevard / Dillon Road which would operate at LOS E in the PM peak hour. Further
improvements at this intersection required to achieve a LOS D or better have not been
recommended due to the close proximity of existing development at the intersection.

Appendix D provides the operational analysis worksheets. Appendix E provides the signal
warrant worksheet for South 96th Street / Campus Drive.




                                                                                          Page 28
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                                                     Traffic Impact Study



C.          Auxiliary Turn Lane Lengths

Turn lane requirements for the roadways surrounding the project area were evaluated using
guidelines from A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets, AASHTO (AASHTO
Greenbook). These recommendations are designed to provide guidance for the construction of
auxiliary lanes for site accesses for the ConocoPhillips Campus.

Table 4 provides the auxiliary turn lane requirements for Site Accesses A, B, C, and D, and the
new intersection South 96th Street / Campus Drive.

Table 4.               Auxiliary Turn Lane Requirements

             Intersection                               Movement                                  2035 Total Length (ft)
                                                       NBL (Triple) 1                             645' (inc. 432' taper)
                                                          SBR                                     370' (inc. 144' taper)
           Site Access A
                                                        EBL (Dual)                                355' (inc. 180' taper)
                                                          EBR                                      640' (inc. 90' taper)
                                                          NBL                                      240' (inc. 90' taper)
           Site Access B                                  EBR                                      140' (inc. 90' taper)
                                                          WBL                                      265' (inc. 90' taper)
          Site Access C2                                  SBR                                     745' (inc. 144' taper)
                                                          NBR                                     170' (inc. 120' taper)
           Site Access D                                  SBL                                     470' (inc. 120' taper)
                                                          WBL                                      165' (inc. 90' taper)
                                                          NBL                                     292' (inc. 192' taper)
        South 96th Street /
                                                          SBR                                     469' (inc. 144' taper)
          Campus Drive
                                                          EBR                                      215' (inc. 90' taper)
1
    At 2013, dual left turn lanes will be required for the NBL. Adequate laneage for this roadway laneage is already provided.
2
    A continuous auxiliary right turn lane is recommended between South 96th Street and this site access.

Conoco Phillips Campus - Louisville, 09-123, 11/06/09
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                       Traffic Impact Study



V.     SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
ConocoPhillips Company is proposing to build a new research and office development in the
City of Louisville, Colorado. The new facility would be located north of US 36 between South
88th Street and Northwest Parkway and was the former location of Storage Technology
Corporation.

The proposed ConocoPhillips Campus site is located northwest of the Northwest Parkway / US
36 interchange. The overall site is approximately 432 acres with the PDP boundary including
390 acres. The current site is a developed parcel in which all existing structures have been
razed and will be replaced with the new development. At build out, the total development will not
exceed 2.5 million square feet (msf). The conceptual layout for the site includes an initial phase
totaling 1.60 msf initial occupancy of which is anticipated in 2013, Phase 2 totaling 0.15 msf of
additional development with initial occupancy thereof anticipated in 2018, and Phase 3 (Build
Out) totaling 0.75 msf of additional development with initial occupancy anticipated in 2032.

The projected traffic generation at build out of the development is approximately 17,500 vehicle-
trips per day. Approximately 2,660 new vehicle trips are anticipated to be added to the road
network during the AM peak hour and 2,455 during the PM peak hour. These numbers reflect
an estimate of the grand total of all trips in and out of the facility, that is, all access drives
combined. The addition of site generated traffic to the background volumes represent 19
percent and 27 percent of total traffic on South 96th Street, just north of US 36, and South 88th
Street, just north of Campus Drive, respectively.

The following phased improvements have been recognized within the traffic impact study.
Figure 16 provides a summary of the recommended major roadway improvements.
Improvements required to accommodate background traffic, which is the component of traffic
volume on the local street network that is not related to the proposed ConocoPhillips
development, are described first. The significant growth on all roads surrounding the
ConocoPhillips Campus will therefore require City of Louisville and other local agencies to
construct roadway improvements to accommodate general growth in the study area.
Improvements necessary to accommodate ConocoPhillips Campus traffic are then enumerated
for 2013 and 2035.

2013 Background Improvements
      Northwest Parkway / South 96th Street - This intersection was assumed to be
      expanded to include a four leg intersection to serve the future redevelopment area east
      of Northwest Parkway in Broomfield.
      McCaslin Boulevard / Dillon Road - The City of Louisville will need to widen the
      westbound Dillon Road approach to McCaslin Boulevard to add a second full-use left
      turn lane. This will provide dual left-turn lanes, one through lane, and one right-turn lane
      for westbound traffic. Currently, there are three lanes (one left-turn lane, one shared
      left-through lane, and one right-turn lane), and the signal timing is inefficient due to the
      need for a split-phase.




                                                                                          Page 32
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                        Traffic Impact Study



2035 Background Improvements
      Dillon Road - Dillon Road should be widened to four continuous through lanes from
      South 88th Street to east of the intersection with South 96th Street.
      South 96th Street - South 96th Street should be widened to four continuous through
      lanes from north of Dillon Road to the intersection with Northwest Parkway.
      Dillon Road / South 96th Street - At Dillon Road and South 96th Street dual left turn
      lanes should be provided for all movements.
      McCaslin Boulevard / Dillon Road - McCaslin Boulevard at the intersection with Dillon
      Road should be widened to provide three continuous through lanes in the northbound
      direction.
      South 96th Street / Northwest Parkway - At South 96th Street and Northwest
      Parkway, a southbound free flowing continuous right turn lane from South 96th Street to
      southbound Northwest Parkway should be provided.
      Northwest Parkway - This roadway should be widened to six continuous through lanes
      from the end of the tolled portion of the Northwest Parkway south to the intersection with
      the eastbound off ramp for US 36.
      McCaslin Boulevard - McCaslin Boulevard should be widened to four continuous
      through lanes north of Coalton Road.

2013 Total Improvements (Additional improvement attributable to the development)
      Campus Drive - Campus Drive should be extended east as a collector street from its
      current terminus near Monarch High School to intersect with South 96th Street at
      Paradise Lane. This is the primary access to the north side of the site. At the
      intersection of Campus Drive / South 96th Street construct a southbound auxiliary right
      turn lane, a northbound auxiliary left turn lane, and an eastbound auxiliary right turn lane.
      Signal warrants were evaluated, and the intersection of Campus Drive (at Paradise
      Lane) and South 96th Street should be signalized with initial construction.
      Internal Road Network - All internal roadways will need to be completed to
      accommodate Phase 1 traffic. Phase 1 involves completion of significant portions of both
      the north and south sides of the site so convenient access will be necessary from Site
      Accesses A, B, C, and D.
              Site Access A  No laneage improvements are required at this time.
              Site Access B  Construct a westbound auxiliary left turn lane and an eastbound
              auxiliary right turn lane for inbound traffic. Separate northbound left turn and
              right turn lanes will be needed at the new site access to accommodate outbound
              traffic.
              Site Access C - This right-in/right-out only (RIRO) access point on Northwest
              Parkway should be constructed to provide direct access to the site to/from
              southbound Northwest Parkway.
              Site Access D  Construct a southbound auxiliary left turn lane and a
              northbound right turn deceleration lane for inbound traffic at this access.
              Outbound traffic will need separate westbound left turn and right turn lanes at the
              site access. The outbound volumes are not high enough at the completion of
              Phase 1 to warrant signalization with initial construction.
              Street A  Construct as a four lane roadway.
              Street B  Construct as a two lane roadway.
              Street C  Construct as a two lane roadway.




                                                                                           Page 33
ConocoPhillips Campus                                                    Traffic Impact Study



              Street D  Construct as a two lane roadway.
              Street E  Construct as a two lane roadway.
              Street F  Construct as a two lane roadway.

2035 Total Improvements (Additional improvement attributable to the development)
      South 88th Street - South 88th Street should be widened to four continuous through
      lanes from Dillon Road to Campus Drive.
      Internal Road Network  Additional laneage improvements required for the 2035 total
      traffic volumes, above those listed for the 2013 scenario, follow:
               Site Access A  Construct triple northbound left turn lanes on Northwest
               Parkway at the site access. Consider that this improvement requires the
               widening of Northwest Parkway surrounding the intersection and may be best
               accomplished at the same time the road widening of South 96th Street occurs.
               Site Access D  This intersection should be signalized when traffic counts show
               that traffic is sufficient to meet the appropriate MUTCD signal warrant.




                                                                                       Page 34
    Boulder Rd.

 Start Time Left Thru Right Peds App. Total Left Thru Right Peds                                      App. Total    Left   Thru Right      Peds   App. Total     Left Thru Right Peds              App. Total   Int. Total
